data.title: SiteGround vs Bluehost: Real Tests to Help You Choose in 2024
data.meta_description: Struggling to choose between SiteGround vs Bluehost? Read this comparison to see real performance tests and data from our hosting survey.
data.text:
Struggling to choose between SiteGround vs Bluehost for hosting your sites? I was too. So I signed up for both and then tested them head-to-head to find out which is better.

In this post, I‚Äôll share the findings of this hands-on comparison and shed some light on the performance of these hosts to help you make the right choice for your needs.

SiteGround vs Bluehost (IN DETAIL)

Let‚Äôs look at these hosts in a couple of main areas:

Features

Performance

User experience

Support

Pricing

Features ‚öôÔ∏è

Now, let‚Äôs compare the features in SiteGround vs Bluehost in a little more detail.

Here is the key to what the emojis mean:

‚ùå ‚Äì the host does not offer this feature on any plan.

‚úÖ ‚Äì the host offers this feature on all of its plans.

‚úÖüí∞ ‚Äì the host offers this feature, but only on the higher-tier plans (or it‚Äôs an add-on that costs extra).

As you can see, both SiteGround and Bluehost offer most of the important features that you need to host a WordPress site (or a different type of website).

However, Bluehost does charge extra for some key features, such as automatic backups. Even with that, Bluehost will still often work out to be cheaper than SiteGround. You could also avoid some of these upcharges by using plugins instead, such as a WordPress backup plugin.

Performance üìà

How quickly your website loads is important for creating a great user experience and maximizing your marketing efforts, so any SiteGround vs Bluehost performance differences should play an important role in your decision.

To put them to the test, we set up our own websites on both hosts and then subjected them to regular performance tests and uptime monitoring.

We‚Äôve been running these ongoing tests for years now, which gives us lots of insights into the performance of both hosts.

Hands-on speed testing results

Here are the results of our hands-on performance testing for both SiteGround and Bluehost.

In general, both hosts did pretty well in our performance tests, with load times well under two seconds for most locations that we run our tests from.

Hands-on uptime test results

To check uptime, we set up an uptime monitor for both hosts and let it run indefinitely.

Here‚Äôs our SiteGround vs Bluehost uptime data from the past few months:

Overall, there‚Äôs no real difference when it comes to uptime, and both hosts performed quite well in our testing.

User experience üßë‚Äçüíª

In general, both SiteGround and Bluehost offer a user-friendly experience for both non-technical and technical users.

Even if you‚Äôve never made a WordPress site, you should have no problem setting one up with either host.

In terms of dashboards, however, there‚Äôs one big difference right away:

SiteGround uses its own custom dashboard tool called Site Tools.

Bluehost has also built some custom dashboard experiences, but Bluehost also gives you full access to cPanel.

If you‚Äôre not familiar with what cPanel is, it‚Äôs kind of the ‚Äústandard‚Äù hosting dashboard experience that many hosts use. SiteGround used to offer cPanel, but SiteGround moved to its 100% custom Site Tools dashboard in 2020.

Which one is better? Well, it really depends on your personal preferences.

If you‚Äôre already familiar with cPanel and you‚Äôve built some of its tools into your workflow, you might prefer Bluehost because you still get full cPanel access.

However, SiteGround‚Äôs Site Tools dashboard is plenty capable and gives you access to a lot of the same functionality that you‚Äôd get with cPanel.

To let you make your own decision, let‚Äôs take a hands-on look at the SiteGround vs Bluehost user experience and dashboards, including what it‚Äôs like to make a WordPress site at each.

SiteGround dashboard and user experience

SiteGround‚Äôs custom hosting dashboard is called Site Tools.

When you‚Äôre just getting started, you get a simple tool to install WordPress and set up your site ‚Äì we cover it in detail in our guide on how to install WordPress on SiteGround.

From there, you can manage your individual sites in a dashboard that looks like this:

In the sidebar, you‚Äôll find a range of different tools to manage areas like performance, security, backups, and so on.

For example, here‚Äôs what it‚Äôs like to use the backup system.

You can also pin your favorite tools to the top so that you can quickly access them, which is a nice bit of customization. You can see this in the first screenshot.

In general, most regular users will not feel like they‚Äôre limited in comparison to cPanel. For example, if you don‚Äôt feel like connecting to your server via FTP, SiteGround offers its own file manager tool, just like cPanel File Manager.

Bluehost dashboard and user experience

Bluehost‚Äôs dashboard is a mix of a custom interface as well as full cPanel access.

To create a new WordPress site, Bluehost offers a simple installer tool ‚Äì our guide on how to install WordPress on Bluehost covers it in more detail.

You can either make a basic WordPress install or use Bluehost‚Äôs WonderSuite features to help you build a complete website.

Once you‚Äôve set up your site, you get a dedicated dashboard for each site that lets you manage key areas:

Overview ‚Äì see basic details and access key areas like cPanel File Manager.

Security ‚Äì manage free SSL certificates and SiteLock (SiteLock costs extra).

Backups ‚Äì you can manage backups if you pay for CodeGuard (some plans offer a free year of CodeGuard, but it costs money after that).

Plugins ‚Äì manage all of the plugins on your site, including activating and updating plugins.

Users ‚Äì manage WordPress users, including resetting a user‚Äôs password.

Speed ‚Äì manage performance features, such as the built-in page caching and Cloudflare integration.

Advanced ‚Äì manage advanced details like databases, SSH keys, access logs, FTP access, phpMyAdmin, etc.

Settings ‚Äì manage key WordPress settings like automatic updates.

If you want to access more advanced tools, Bluehost still lets you access the full cPanel interface from the Advanced tab in your dashboard ‚Äì just click the Manage button next to cPanel.

Having access to cPanel is a nice bonus for more experienced users who want to make use of more advanced tools. However, for non-technical users, you might never even need to interact with this area.

Support üñ±Ô∏è

Both SiteGround and Bluehost offer 24/7 support via a variety of channels, so you‚Äôll have no problem getting in touch with someone if you need some help.

Here‚Äôs a quick table comparing some key details:

Pricing üíµ

In general, Bluehost is a little bit cheaper than SiteGround. However, Bluehost no longer offers unlimited websites on its plans, while SiteGround still allows unlimited websites (though the plans still have storage limits).

When it comes to Bluehost vs SiteGround pricing, there are a lot of variables to consider.

First off, both SiteGround and Bluehost use a promotional pricing strategy to give you a discounted price on your first billing cycle (which is usually a year, if you pay for the full year upfront).

However, once that first billing cycle ends and you need to renew your account, you‚Äôll need to pay the ‚Äúregular‚Äù price, which can often be more than double the promotional price.

As such, it‚Äôs important to consider both prices when making your decision. In general, Bluehost is cheaper than SiteGround when it comes to the regular price, even though the promotional prices are similar.

For example, with promotional pricing, the entry-level plan costs $2.99 per month at SiteGround and $1.99 per month at Bluehost.

Same same, right?

However, after the first year, that same plan would cost $17.99 per month at SiteGround, but only $11.99 per month at Bluehost.

Here are some tables to compare pricing at SiteGround and Bluehost for different plan tiers ‚Äì for more details, check out our full guides to SiteGround pricing and Bluehost pricing.

Final thoughts on Bluehost vs SiteGround üèÅ

In the end, there‚Äôs no single winner when it comes to choosing between SiteGround vs Bluehost.

Rather than trying to recommend one host to every single person who reads this, I think it‚Äôs more useful to lay out the situations in which you might want to pick one of them over the other (or where a different host might be an even better option than both Bluehost and SiteGround).

FAQs about SiteGround and Bluehost üí°

Lastly, let‚Äôs run over a few common questions that you might have about these two hosts:

Do you still have any questions about choosing between SiteGround and Bluehost for your website(s)? Let us know in the comments and we‚Äôll try to help!

Yay! üéâ You made it to the end of the article!
